title: Australia news live: Jacinta Price says some Liberals still back nuclear as ‘cleanest, greenest’ form of energy
snippets:
Follow today’s news live

  • Sussan Ley leaves possibility open of Coalition abandoning net zero targets but insists ‘there won’t be a climate war’
  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Ryan speaks after winning re-election in Kooyong

The freshly re-elected teal independent Monique Ryan has just been speaking on RN. She said she won because of her on-the-ground approach in her electorate:

Over the last three years, since I was elected to represent Kooyong I’ve worked very hard to fulfil the contract that I made with my community, which is that I will listen to them and try to represent them as effectively as I can on the things that matter to them.

I have a great team who’ve responded to issues within the electorate really quickly and effectively, and I heard many times when people how grateful they were for help with the sorts of things that they reach out to the team for.

This is a historic moment in the pursuit of truth, justice and accountability for the victims of the downing of flight MH17, and their families and loved ones.

The ICAO council found that Russia breached the prohibition under international law on the use of weapons against civil aircraft in flight and is responsible for the loss of 298 innocent lives, including 38 who called Australia home.

Continue reading...

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Ryan speaks after winning re-election in Kooyong

Over the last three years, since I was elected to represent Kooyong I’ve worked very hard to fulfil the contract that I made with my community, which is that I will listen to them and try to represent them as effectively as I can on the things that matter to them.

I have a great team who’ve responded to issues within the electorate really quickly and effectively, and I heard many times when people how grateful they were for help with the sorts of things that they reach out to the team for.

This is a historic moment in the pursuit of truth, justice and accountability for the victims of the downing of flight MH17, and their families and loved ones.

titles: Australia news live: Jacinta Price says some Liberals still back nuclear as ‘cleanest, greenest’ form of energy
Australia news live: Jacinta Price says some Liberals still back nuclear as ‘cleanest, greenest’ form of energy
summary: Sussan Ley has hinted at the possibility of the Coalition reconsidering its commitment to net zero targets, emphasizing there will not be a "climate war." Meanwhile, Monique Ryan, a teal independent, has been re-elected in Kooyong, attributing her victory to her effective local engagement and responsiveness to community issues. Additionally, the ICAO council has determined that Russia violated international law by using weapons against civil aircraft in flight, holding it responsible for the downing of flight MH17 and the loss of 298 lives, including 38 Australians.
constructiveness_reason: The story provides a clear understanding of the political dynamics in Australia, including discussions on energy policy and climate change. It also highlights the progress made by a local leader in engaging with her community. The mention of Russia's violation of international law increases awareness of global issues. However, it does not offer explicit solutions or innovations.

title: Distinguishing between edible and poisonous fungi is difficult, mushroom expert tells Erin Patterson trial

Dr Thomas May, a mycologist or scientist specialising in fungi, appeared in Patterson’s trial on Tuesday.

title: M&S says some personal data was taken in cyber-attack
snippets:
Data does not include usable payment or card details, or passwords, says Marks & Spencer

  • Business live – latest updates

Marks & Spencer has said for the first time that some personal customer information was taken in the cyber-attack that has crippled its online operation for more than three weeks.

Since the retailer’s IT systems were hit by a ransomware attack, it has not been taking online orders, and the availability of some products in its stores has been affected after it took some of its systems offline in response.

Continue reading...

Data does not include usable payment or card details, or passwords, says Marks & Spencer

  • Business live – latest updates

Marks & Spencer has said for the first time that some personal customer information was taken in the cyber-attack that has crippled its online operation for more than three weeks.

Since the retailer’s IT systems were hit by a ransomware attack, it has not been taking online orders, and the availability of some products in its stores has been affected after it took some of its systems offline in response.

Continue reading...
titles: M&S says some personal data was taken in cyber-attack
M&S says some personal data was taken in cyber-attack
summary: Marks & Spencer confirmed that personal customer information was compromised in a ransomware attack that has disrupted its online operations for over three weeks. The attack led to the retailer halting online orders and impacted product availability in stores. However, Marks & Spencer assured that the stolen data does not include usable payment details, card information, or passwords.
constructiveness_reason: The story informs readers about a significant cyber-attack on Marks & Spencer, providing useful context about the impact of such attacks on businesses and customers. However, it does not report on solutions or improvements, nor does it provide actionable insights for readers to protect themselves from similar attacks.

title: Democratic state treasurers rip GOP over budget bill — ‘taxing Barbies and G.I. Joes if you can even find them on store shelves’

summary: Washington State Treasurer Mike Pellicciotti warned that the combination of the budget, tariff policy, and reductions in federal programs could result in domestic investors moving their investments abroad. This outflow is attributed to the financial changes and cuts affecting their decisions.
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful information about the potential impact of the budget bill and tariff policy on domestic investors. However, it doesn't offer solutions or improvements, and the awareness it raises is limited to the potential for investment outflow.

title: Four Powerful Lasers Illuminate the Milky Way and Echo Ancient Traditions
snippets: In Chile’s desert skies, four lasers from ESO’s telescope revive ancient Andean beliefs about a sacred, layered universe guided by the power of four. Four powerful laser beams from ESO’s Very Large Telescope (VLT) reach deep into the heart of the Milky Way in this striking image. Cutting through a star-filled night, the lasers are [...]
titles: Four Powerful Lasers Illuminate the Milky Way and Echo Ancient Traditions
summary: In Chile, four powerful lasers from the European Southern Observatory's Very Large Telescope (VLT) were used to illuminate the Milky Way, creating a visually striking image. This event also resonates with ancient Andean traditions, which revered a universe structured in sacred layers and guided by the power of four. This blending of modern astronomy with historical beliefs highlights a unique intersection of science and culture.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides a deeper understanding of how modern astronomy can intersect with historical beliefs, contributing to cultural awareness. However, it does not provide actionable insights or report on solutions or improvements.

title: Gravity’s Quantum Secret: “Theory of Everything” Could Unite the Forces of Nature
snippets: A bold new quantum theory of gravity may finally bridge the long-standing rift between Einstein’s general relativity and quantum field theory. This potential “Theory of Everything” could answer some of the deepest mysteries in science—from black hole singularities to the origins of the universe—while inviting the global scientific community to contribute to the final proof. [...]
titles: Gravity’s Quantum Secret: “Theory of Everything” Could Unite the Forces of Nature
summary: A new quantum gravity theory proposes a "Theory of Everything" that aims to unify Einstein's general relativity with quantum field theory, potentially solving major scientific mysteries such as black hole singularities and the universe's origins. This groundbreaking approach invites global scientific collaboration for its validation.
constructiveness_reason: This story is highly constructive. It reports on a significant innovation in the field of physics that could solve major scientific mysteries. The story invites global scientific collaboration for validation, thus empowering the scientific community.

title: Why Do Some Ancient Creatures Leave Fossils While Others Disappear?
snippets: Fossilization favors larger, protein-rich animals because they create oxygen-poor conditions that slow decay, helping explain gaps in the fossil record and the dominance of arthropods in ancient deposits. Have you ever wondered why we find fossils of some ancient creatures, but others seem to disappear without a trace? A fascinating new study from the University [...]
titles: Why Do Some Ancient Creatures Leave Fossils While Others Disappear?
summary: A new study reveals that fossilization is more likely to occur in larger, protein-rich animals. This is because such organisms create oxygen-poor environments that slow down decay, providing insight into why the fossil record has gaps and why arthropods are prevalent in ancient deposits.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides useful insights into the process of fossilization and why the fossil record has gaps. It increases the reader's understanding of paleontology, but it does not report on solutions or improvements.

title: Harvard Scientists Solve 100-Year Mystery of Bizarre 508-Million-Year-Old Arthropod
snippets: Helmetia expansa was found to have walking legs and molting behavior, changing assumptions about its mobility and growth. For more than a century, the Cambrian arthropod Helmetia expansa remained a mystery. Discovered in 1918 by paleontologist Charles Doolittle Walcott, it was initially identified as a crustacean. Although frequently mentioned in scientific literature, the species had [...]
titles: Harvard Scientists Solve 100-Year Mystery of Bizarre 508-Million-Year-Old Arthropod
summary: Harvard scientists have resolved a century-old mystery surrounding the Cambrian arthropod Helmetia expansa, discovered in 1918. Previously thought to be a crustacean, new findings reveal that Helmetia had walking legs and exhibited molting behavior, indicating a different level of mobility and growth than initially assumed. This discovery, based on fossils from the Burgess Shale, challenges earlier assumptions about the species' classification and lifestyle.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides readers with a deeper understanding of a long-standing scientific mystery. It reports on the progress made by scientists in reclassifying a species, contributing to the field of paleontology and biology. The story also increases awareness about the scientific process of studying fossils and the potential for new discoveries.

title: Radical photon idea could rewrite standard model of particle physics

titles: Radical photon idea could rewrite standard model of particle physics
summary: Recent experiments focusing on hydrogen atoms are poised to potentially uncover the existence of particles previously considered impossible by traditional physics. These investigations aim to determine if such particles, once thought to be purely theoretical, actually exist in reality.
constructiveness_reason: This story is informative and provides useful context about ongoing research in particle physics. It does not explicitly report on solutions or improvements, but it does highlight attempts to solve a problem in the field of physics. It increases awareness about the potential for new discoveries in physics, but lacks some depth about the implications of these potential findings.
